title: Mark Rothko’s ‘Blue Over Red’ Could Top $25 Million
text:
Text size

Mark Rothko’s Blue Over Red from 1953, a critical period during which the artist developed his signature style of abstraction, will headline a Sotheby’s contemporary art auction in New York on Nov. 14.

The painting is expected to fetch between $25 million and $35 million, and will be on public view at Sotheby’s York Avenue galleries beginning Nov. 1.

A testament to the importance of this period in Rothko’s career, eight of the 16 paintings he created in 1953 are in permanent museum collections, including the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, and the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C., Sotheby’s said.

“Some of the most moving paintings Rothko ever made date to the year of 1953,” David Galperin, head of Sotheby’s evening auctions of contemporary art in New York, said in a statement.

In 1952, Rothko moved his studio to 106 West 53rd St., down the street from the Museum of Modern Art.

“Sunlight poured into his new high-ceilinged studio, resulting in these intensely vivid, brightly-colored paintings that appear to be illuminated from within. The exuberant palette and atmospheric depth of his Blue Over Red reflects the mastery of this transformative period in Rothko’s career,” Galperin said.

Blue Over Red was offered for sale from an anonymous European collector, who has held the painting since 2007, according to Sotheby’s. Other previous prominent owners include famed New York dealer and collector Harold Diamond, who specialized in 20th-century works, and Baltimore collectors Israel and Selma Rosen, who sold the work at an auction in 2005 for $5.6 million.

Rothko’s color-block paintings have been highly sought after. His auction record was set by the 1961 Orange, Red, Yellow, which realized $86.9 million at Christie’s New York in May 2012.

His 1960 Untitled, which features a subdued color palette of deep burgundy, warm blush, royal blue, black grey, and ephemeral cloud-white, sold for $50.1 million at Sotheby’s this spring on behalf of San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.

To date, seven Rothko paintings have sold above $50 million, and 28 works have sold above $20 million, according to the Artnet’s price database.
description: The masterpiece will headline Sotheby’s Nov. 14 contemporary art sale
